unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Laptop Battery Life: Interpreting a $p$-Value
question_text: When Carter bought his new laptop computer, the sales person told him that the average battery life was 5 5 hours and that the number of hours of battery life is approximately normally distributed. After using the computer for a few days, Carter began to have his doubts. The next 10 10 times that Carter used his computer, he kept track of how long it took for the battery to drain. The sample average was 4.25 4.25 . Conducting a one-sided significance test, he found the p p -value to be 0.038 0.038 . What is the best way to interpret this p p -value in the context of this situation?

choices.text: A p p -value as small as 0.038 0.038 gives Carter good reason to doubt that the average battery life of his laptop really is 5 5 hours.
If the average battery life really is 5 5 hours, then a sample of 10 10 observations having a sample mean of 4.25 4.25 hours or lower would only occur about 3.8 % 3.8 % of the time.
When 10 10 observations are made, the battery life will be as low as 4.25 4.25 hours in 3.8 % 3.8 % of the observations.
There is a 3.8 % 3.8 % chance that Carter's laptop computer battery will last for 4.25 4.25 hours anytime he uses it.
Only 3.8 % 3.8 % of all laptop batteries will last as long as 5 5 hours.
